fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicative encodings of (higher) inductive types
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @inproceedings{awodey-frey-speight-2018, author = {Awodey, Steve and Frey, Jonas and Speight, Sam}, address = {Oxford, United Kingdom}, publisher = {Association for Computing Machinery}, booktitle = {Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science}, year = {2018}, doi = {10.1145/3209108.3209130}, isbn = {978-1-4503-5583-4}, pages = {76--85}, title = {Impredicative Encodings of (Higher) Inductive Types}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Postulating an impredicative universe in dependent type theory allows System F style encodings of finitary inductive types, but these fail to satisfy the relevant η-equalities and consequently do not admit dependent eliminators. To recover η and dependent elimination, we present a method to construct refinements of these impredicative encodings, using ideas from homotopy type theory. We then extend our method to construct impredicative encodings of some higher inductive types, such as 1-truncation and the unit circle S1.

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: CSL ’24: 32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic 2024

fr:meta.fr:link: CSL ’24: 32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic 2024

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Realisability semantics of parametric polymorphism, general references and recursive types, Semantics of Types for Mutable State

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Most practical programming languages have side effects: state, input-output, errors, etc.
Monads capture the structure of side effects (Moggi, Wadler).
State means being able to interact with the computer’s memory; references or pointers govern access to a location in memory.
The syntax of state varies along three axes:

html:p.html:em: What kind of things can be stored in memory cells?
When can these memory cells be allocated?
What equations hold of stateful computations?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Storing only integers or other first-order data.
Models of very extensional equational theory including “garbage collection” found by Plotkin, Power; Staton. Adapted to “full ground store” (storage of pointers) by Kammar, Levy, Moss, and Staton.
Extensionality of models lost when moving to higher-order storage.
An extreme point in the design space...
Deeply impredicative: heap contains elements of arbitrary types.
\Longrightarrow guarded recursion (step-indexing) used to break the circularity.
An equational theory of higher-order store in which reads to the heap leave behind “breadcrumbs”.
Consider two implementations of an “counter” object:

html:p.html:em: What is the relationship between \mathsf {posCounter} and \mathsf {negCounter}?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: They appear to be indistinguishable. Indeed, they are “observationally equivalent”!

Observational equivalence is an extremely weak property: indistinguishability under observations of ground type only. It would be great if we could instead deduce an absolute equation: \color {red}\vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter} \colon \mathsf {Counter} (No cheating: we want “standard” models without extensional collapse or logical relation.)
We add two additional rules to the equational theory of guarded higher-order dynamic allocation.

CELL UNIVALENCE. For f^+\colon A\to B and f^-\colon B\to A with x:B\vdash f^+{\mathopen {}\left (f^-{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\equiv x and x\colon A\vdash f^-{\mathopen {}\left (f^+{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} \equiv x we have:
The theory of univalent reference types derives \vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter}.
The function \mathsf {neg} \colon \mathsf {Integer}\to \mathsf {Integer} is inverse to itself; therefore, apply CELL UNIVALENCE with f^+ \equiv f^- \equiv \mathsf {neg} and simplify.

fr:title.text: Can we find a reasonable model of this theory???

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Can we find a reasonable model of this theory???

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let’s start with the non-univalent fragment (“guarded higher-order dynamic allocation”).

fr:title.text: Models of guarded higher order dynamic allocation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Models of guarded higher order dynamic allocation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: S., Gratzer, and Birkedal (2022) found synthetic denotational semantics for guarded higher-order dynamic allocation in an impredicative version of guarded dependent type theory (iGDTT).
Guarded recursion needed to solve the domain equation; impredicativity needed to define the monad (b/c \mathsf {Heap} is large).

Our main observation is that a slight variation on SGB’22 suffices to model univalent reference types, so long as both \mathbf {FinSet} and \mathbf {Set} are both univalent universes in the sense of Voevodsky.

html:ol.html:li: Univalence of \mathbf {FinSet} implies the LAYOUT UNIVALENCE rule.
Univalence of \mathbf {Set} implies the CELL UNIVALENCE rule.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We therefore need an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory.
We define iGHoTT to be the extension of Martin-Löf’s intensional type theory by the following additional features:

html:ol.html:li: homotopy type theory: the univalence axiom
guarded recursion: later modality \mathord {\blacktriangleright } and solutions to guarded fixed points
a univalent impredicative universe, i.e. a universe \mathcal {S}\in \mathcal {U} closed under families of \mathcal {S}-small types indexed in a \mathcal {U}-small type.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In iGHoTT, we can define a model of univalent reference types. The real question is whether we can find a model of iGHoTT.
Palombi and S. (2023) have contributed a modular method for building models of (non-univalent) guarded dependent type theory over an arbitrary base topos. As applied by SGB’22:

html:ol.html:li: Any realisability topos \mathcal {E} contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}}.

Then the relative presheaf topos \mathcal {F} :\equiv {\mathopen {}\left [\mathbb {O}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathcal {E}\right ]\mathclose {}} is a model of guarded recursion and contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {F}} defined from \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}} by Hofmann—Streicher lifting.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have not gotten around to adapting the SGB’22 model of iGDTT to obtain a model of iGHoTT, which is much more complicated.

html:ol.html:li: Let \mathbb {A} be a partial combinatory algebra.
Let \square be a suitable internal cube category in \mathbf {PER}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}, and let \mathbb {O} be an internal well-founded order in the same.

Then the category of internal presheaves of assemblies {\mathopen {}\left [{\mathopen {}\left (\square \times \mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}} is expected to form a model of iGHoTT{}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Impredicative HoTT via cubical assemblies due to Awodey et al. and studied by Uemura, Swan.
Guarded HoTT via \square \times \mathbb {O} due to Birkedal et al. (2019).

fr:title.text: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Even if internal presheaves of assemblies on \square \times \mathbb {O} works, the resulting model will be uncanonical from the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-categorical standpoint.
For example, if \mathbb {O}=\omega , we shall not have defined the “internal (pre)-{\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-topos of trees” in cubical assemblies.

More canonical approach would be to take internal presheaves on any \mathcal {S}-small well-founded order \mathbb {O} internal to the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-category \mathcal {E} presented by {\mathopen {}\left [\square ^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}}. This may introduce coherence problems that we are currently unprepared for.

fr:title.text: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:mainmatter.html:p: SGB’22 were not the first to combine guarded recursion with realisability to model higher-order dynamic allocation; see Birkedal, Støvring, and Thamsborg (2010).

However, op.cit. relied on a specific realisability model based on an untyped domain model of a stateful language; in contrast, the model construction of SGB’22 applies uniformly for any pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {E},\mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}.
Thus SGB’22 showed that realisability is inessential: if we find any other viable source of impredicative universes besides realisability, SGB’22 would apply there too.
Thanks!

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Towards univalent reference types

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: CSL ’24: 32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic 2024

fr:meta.fr:link: CSL ’24: 32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic 2024

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @inproceedings{sterling-gratzer-birkedal-2024-univalent, author = {Sterling, Jonathan and Gratzer, Daniel and Birkedal, Lars}, title = {{Towards Univalent Reference Types: The Impact of Univalence on Denotational Semantics}}, booktitle = {32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL 2024)}, pages = {47:1--47:21}, series = {Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs)}, ISBN = {978-3-95977-310-2}, ISSN = {1868-8969}, year = {2024}, volume = {288}, editor = {Murano, Aniello and Silva, Alexandra}, publisher = {Schloss Dagstuhl -- Leibniz-Zentrum f{\"u}r Informatik}, address = {Dagstuhl, Germany}, doi = {10.4230/LIPIcs.CSL.2024.47}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We develop a denotational semantics for general reference types in an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory, an adaptation of synthetic guarded domain theory to Voevodsky’s univalent foundations. We observe for the first time the profound impact of univalence on the denotational semantics of mutable state. Univalence automatically ensures that all computations are invariant under symmetries of the heap—a bountiful source of program equivalences. In particular, even the most simplistic univalent model enjoys many new program equivalences that do not hold when the same constructions are carried out in the universes of traditional set-level (extensional) type theory.

Let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative universe pair with A:\mathcal {V} such that \mathsf {INatStr} is the displayed reflection algebra of incoherent naturality structures over the product \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X of all reflection algebras. We define a further displayed reflection algebra \mathsf {SemiCoh} over \mathsf {INatStr} of “semicoherence structures” associating to each incoherent naturality structure one dimension of coherence data for binary compositions of homomorphisms.
In particular, we define \mathsf {SemiCoh} over \widetilde {\mathsf {INatStr}} as follows, employing our notion of homotopy between homomorphisms:

To define the displayed algebra structure \bar \eta _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}, we will use the contractibility of singletons several times. In particular, given {\mathopen {}\left (Y,f\right )\mathclose {}} where Y:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} and f:X\multimap Y, the algebra component \eta _{Y} is completely determined by the homotopy \eta _{f} :{\eta _{Y}} \sim _{A\to Y} {f \circ \eta _{X}}; likewise, by our characterization of paths between homomorphisms, the pair {\mathopen {}\left (h,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} is uniquely determined. Therefore, we may define \bar \eta _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}} to be the unique function satisfying the following equation:

Given an element u:\widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}}, we shall write \epsilon _{u},\vartheta _{u} for the components of its underlying incoherent naturality structure \pi _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}u and \varsigma _{u} : \mathsf {SemiCoh}[\pi _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}u] for the semicoherence structure itself.
This definition is similar to that of Awodey, Frey, and Speight, except that we do not impose any coherence law for identities.

Let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative universe pair with A:\mathcal {V} a type in the outer universe, so that we may form the product \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X of all reflection algebras in \mathcal {U} under A. To express the data of the components of a given u:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X being preserved by all homomorphisms and thus representing “cones” over the identity functor on {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, we define a displayed reflection algebra \mathsf {INatStr} of “incoherent naturality structures” over \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{X} as follows:

Given an element u:\widetilde {\mathsf {INatStr}}, we will write \epsilon _{u} : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X for the first component \pi _{\mathsf {INatStr}}u and \vartheta _{u} : \mathsf {INatStr}[\epsilon _{u}] for the second component.
This definition is equivalent to one given by Awodey, Frey, and Speight.

Working in univalent foundations, let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be a pair of not-necessarily-univalent universes such that \mathcal {U} is closed under \mathcal {V}-small products of \mathcal {U}-small types; then the subuniverse inclusion {\mathcal {U}}\xrightarrow {{j}}{\mathcal {V}} is reflective. This argument will combine ideas due to Awodey, Frey, Speight, and Shulman. For any type A:\mathcal {V}, we will define the reflection of A in \mathcal {U} in several steps.

Let \mathcal {U} be a subuniverse of \mathcal {V} and let A:\mathcal {V} be a type. A reflection algebra X under A in \mathcal {U} is defined to be a type UX:\mathcal {U} together with a function {A}\xrightarrow {{\eta _{X}}}{UX}. A homomorphism f of reflection algebras from X to Y is given by a function {UX}\xrightarrow {{Uf}}{UY} together with a homotopy \eta _{f} : {\eta _{Y}} \sim _{A\to Y} {Uf\circ \eta _X}.
When it causes no ambiguity, we will write X:\mathcal {U} for the underlying type UX of a given reflection algebra X; likewise, we will write f x rather than Uf x.

fr:title.text: The type of reflection algebras and homomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The type of reflection algebras and homomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will write {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} :\equiv \mathchoice {\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:\mathcal {U}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:\mathcal {U}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:\mathcal {U}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:\mathcal {U}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{A\to X} for the type of reflection algebras under A; given two reflection algebras X,Y:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} we will write {\mathopen {}\left (X\multimap Y\right )\mathclose {}} :\equiv \mathchoice {\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (f:X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (f:X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (f:X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (f:X\to Y\right )\mathclose {}}}} {\eta _{Y}} \sim _{A\to Y} {f\circ \eta _{X}} for the type of homomorphisms of reflection algebras.

fr:title.text: Identity and composition of reflection algebra homomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity and composition of reflection algebra homomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} be a reflection algebra; we define the identity homomorphism 1_{X}:X\multimap X on X as follows:

Now let Y,Z:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} be two further reflection algebras and let f : X\multimap Y and g : Y\multimap Z be two homomorphisms of reflection algebras. The composite homomorphism f;g : X\multimap Z is defined like so:

Given a pair of reflection algebras X,Y:{\mathcal {U}}\downarrow {A} and a pair of homomorphisms f,g : X\multimap Y, a homotopy from f to g is defined to be a homotopy \phi : {Uf} \sim _{X\to Y} {Ug} between the underlying functions together with a witness \bar {\phi } of the following coherence:
We shall write {f} \sim _{X\multimap Y} {g} for the type of homotopies from the homomorphism f to the homomorphism g.

Given a path of reflection algebras X,Y:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} and a homomorphism f : X\multimap Y, the type \mathchoice {\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g:X\multimap Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g:X\multimap Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g:X\multimap Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \sum _{{\mathopen {}\left (g:X\multimap Y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{{g} \sim _{X\multimap Y} {f}} of homomorphisms equipped with a homotopy to f is contractible, by function extensionality and the characterization of path spaces in dependent sums. Hence it follows that the canonical map {f} =_{X\multimap Y} {g}\to {f} \sim _{X\multimap Y} {g} is an equivalence.

Given a type K and a family of reflection algebras X : K\to {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} such that the dependent product \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}U{\mathopen {}\left (Xk\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {U}, we may define the product of product of reflection algebras \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (k:K\right )\mathclose {}}}}Xk to have the following structure map:

Let X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} be a reflection algebra; a displayed reflection algebra Y over X is defined to be a dependent type \bar {U}Y : X \to \mathcal {U} together with a dependent function \bar {\eta }_{Y} : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (a:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\bar {U}Y{\mathopen {}\left (\eta _{X}a\right )\mathclose {}}}.
We will write Y[x] for \bar {U}Yx.

Given a displayed reflection algebra Y over a reflection algebra X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, we may define the total reflection algebra \widetilde {Y}:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} of Y as follows:
The projection function {U\widetilde {Y}}\xrightarrow {{\pi _1}}{UX} extends to a homomorphism of reflection algebras \pi _{Y}:\widetilde {Y}\multimap X as follows:

fr:title.text: Displayed reflection algebras over displayed reflection algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Displayed reflection algebras over displayed reflection algebras

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If Y is a displayed reflection algebra over a reflection algebra X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, we define a displayed reflection algebra over Y to be a displayed reflection algebra in the original sense over the total reflection algebra \widetilde {Y} corresponding to Y.

Letting \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative pair of universes with A:\mathcal {V} a type in the outer universe, our goal is to construct a limit cone over the identity functor in the (∞,1)-category {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} of reflection algebras in \mathcal {U} under A:\mathcal {V}, in order to prove that there is an initial reflection algebra. Even though we do not have access to the fully coherent language of (∞,1)-category theory in univalent foundations, we can specify the coherence structure that we need in order to obtain our result.

Our first step is describe a classifying reflection algebra for fully incoherent cones over the identity functor on {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, which we do by means of a displayed reflection algebra of incoherent naturality structures on the product of all reflection algebras.

Let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative universe pair with A:\mathcal {V} a type in the outer universe, so that we may form the product \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X of all reflection algebras in \mathcal {U} under A. To express the data of the components of a given u:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X being preserved by all homomorphisms and thus representing “cones” over the identity functor on {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, we define a displayed reflection algebra \mathsf {INatStr} of “incoherent naturality structures” over \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{X} as follows:

Given an element u:\widetilde {\mathsf {INatStr}}, we will write \epsilon _{u} : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X for the first component \pi _{\mathsf {INatStr}}u and \vartheta _{u} : \mathsf {INatStr}[\epsilon _{u}] for the second component.
This definition is equivalent to one given by Awodey, Frey, and Speight.

As suggested by the name, the data of an incoherent naturality structure over a family u:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}UX is not particularly coherent. It will happen that for our goals, we need only add a single dimension of additional coherence data governing the behavior of the naturality structure on binary compositions of homomorphisms. This will give us a classifier for what we shall refer to as “semicoherent” cones over the identity functor on {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}.

Let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative universe pair with A:\mathcal {V} such that \mathsf {INatStr} is the displayed reflection algebra of incoherent naturality structures over the product \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X of all reflection algebras. We define a further displayed reflection algebra \mathsf {SemiCoh} over \mathsf {INatStr} of “semicoherence structures” associating to each incoherent naturality structure one dimension of coherence data for binary compositions of homomorphisms.
In particular, we define \mathsf {SemiCoh} over \widetilde {\mathsf {INatStr}} as follows, employing our notion of homotopy between homomorphisms:

To define the displayed algebra structure \bar \eta _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}, we will use the contractibility of singletons several times. In particular, given {\mathopen {}\left (Y,f\right )\mathclose {}} where Y:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} and f:X\multimap Y, the algebra component \eta _{Y} is completely determined by the homotopy \eta _{f} :{\eta _{Y}} \sim _{A\to Y} {f \circ \eta _{X}}; likewise, by our characterization of paths between homomorphisms, the pair {\mathopen {}\left (h,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} is uniquely determined. Therefore, we may define \bar \eta _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}} to be the unique function satisfying the following equation:

Given an element u:\widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}}, we shall write \epsilon _{u},\vartheta _{u} for the components of its underlying incoherent naturality structure \pi _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}u and \varsigma _{u} : \mathsf {SemiCoh}[\pi _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}u] for the semicoherence structure itself.
This definition is similar to that of Awodey, Frey, and Speight, except that we do not impose any coherence law for identities.

By the contractibility of singletons and our characterization of paths between homomorphisms, the definition of semicoherence structures is equivalent to following more direct formulation that avoids the additional cell \phi :

Our reason for choosing the more complex definition involving {\mathopen {}\left (h,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} is that the extra flexibility comes in handy in our results, as suggested by Michael Shulman in private communication.

fr:title.text: A generic cone over the identity functor and its generic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A generic cone over the identity functor and its generic element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Letting I :\equiv \widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}} be the total algebra of the displayed reflection algebra of semicoherence structures, we may define a dependent function p_{\bullet } : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}} I\multimap X exhibiting a “incoherent cone” from I onto the identity functor on {A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}. In particular, we define the components of p_{\bullet } as follows:

Above we have used the definition of the structure map on the total reflection algebra as well as that of the displayed structure map on \mathsf {SemiCoh} over \mathsf {INatStr} over \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}X. We shall refer to p_{\bullet } as the generic cone over the identity functor, with the caveat that we have not formally established it as a “cone” of any kind. Furthermore, we shall refer to the component p_{I}:I\multimap I as the generic element of the generic cone.

fr:title.text: Quasi-idempotence of the generic element of the generic cone

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quasi-idempotence of the generic element of the generic cone

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The generic element p_{I}:I\multimap I of the generic cone p_{\bullet }:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}I\multimap X under I \equiv \widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}} can be equipped with the structure of a pre-idempotent. In particular, we may define a homotopy \chi : {p_{I};p_{I}} \sim _{I\multimap I} {p_{I}} using the incoherent naturality structure of any element of I.

That the higher identification \bar \chi {a} : \eta _{p_{I}}a = \eta _{p_{I};p_{I}}\bullet \vartheta _{\eta _{I}a}p_{I} may be defined by reflexivity follows from the definition of \eta _{I}a, the computation of composite homomorphisms, and the fact that \eta _{p_{I}}a is also defined by reflexivity; in particular, we compute:

We will use the semicoherence structure associated to any element of I to exhibit the underlying function p_{I}:I\to I of the generic element as a quasi-idempotent in the sense of Shulman. In particular, we must exhibit for each u:I an identification \psi : \mathsf {ap}_{p_{I}}{\mathopen {}\left (\chi u\right )\mathclose {}} = \chi {\mathopen {}\left (p_{I}u\right )\mathclose {}}. Unfolding definitions, this means to identify \mathsf {ap}_{p_{I}}{\mathopen {}\left (\vartheta _{u}p_{I}\right )\mathclose {}} with \vartheta _{p_{I}u}p_{I}.
From the semicoherence structure \varsigma _{u} : \mathsf {SemiCoh}[\pi _{\mathsf {SemiCoh}}u] we obtain the following identification:

Canceling \vartheta _{u}p_{I}, unfolding the definition of \chi , and recalling that p_{I}u \equiv \epsilon _{u}I by definition, we obtain the desired identification \mathsf {ap}_{p_{I}}{\mathopen {}\left (\vartheta _{u}p_{I}\right )\mathclose {}}=\vartheta _{p_{I}u}p_{I}.
Therefore, the underlying function p_{I}:I\to I has the structure of a quasi-idempotent.

fr:title.text: Splitting the generic element of the generic cone

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Splitting the generic element of the generic cone

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The underlying function p_{I}:I\to I of the generic element p_{I}:I\multimap I of the generic cone p_{\bullet }:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}I\multimap X under I \equiv \widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}} has been equipped with the structure of a quasi-idempotent in the sense of Shulman, so we may split it.

In particular, the construction of Shulman gives us a type J together with a retraction r : I\to J and a section s : J \to I witnessed by a homotopy \rho :{s;r} \sim _{J\to J} {1_{J}}, such that r;s\equiv p_{I} : I \to I definitionally. Our goal is to lift this splitting of the underlying function p_{I}:I\to I to a splitting of the homomorphism p_{I}:I\multimap I.

We may equip J with the structure of a reflection algebra by setting \eta _{J} :\equiv \eta _{I};r, making r : I \multimap J a homomorphism of algebras definitionally, i.e. \eta _{r}a:\equiv \mathsf {refl}. To exhibit s : J \multimap I as a homomorphism of algebras, we may likewise use reflexivity:
That the above is well-defined can be deduced as follows, using the fact that the splitting of p_{I}\equiv r;s is definitional and that p_{I} is a definitional homomorphism:
We have to check that the homotopy of functions \rho : {s;r} \sim _{J\to J} {1_{J}} lifts to a homotopy of homomorphisms. In particular, we must construct the coherence \bar \rho specified below:

Note that \eta _{1_{J}} is reflexivity; we compute the other side of the desired identificiation \bar \rho a by unfolding definitions (e.g. that of identities and compositions of homomorphisms) and using basic path algebra:

Therefore, to construct \bar \rho a is suffices to identify \rho {\mathopen {}\left (r{\mathopen {}\left (\eta _{I}a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} with reflexivity. To do so, we will use an argument suggested by Shulman in private conversation. We recall from Theorem 3.3 of Shulman that the homotopy \rho induces a new witness of pre-idempotency for p_{I}, namely \chi ' x :\equiv \mathsf {ap}_{s}{\mathopen {}\left (\rho {\mathopen {}\left (rx\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} and that by Theorem 7.1 of the same, this homotopy may be identified with our original witness \chi : {p_{I};p_{I}} \sim _{I\to I} {p_{I}}. Therefore we have \mathsf {ap}_{s}{\mathopen {}\left (\rho {\mathopen {}\left (rx\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = \vartheta _{x}p_{I}; because s is a section of r, this implies that \rho {\mathopen {}\left (r x\right )\mathclose {}} = \mathsf {ap}_{r}{\mathopen {}\left (\vartheta _{x}p_{I}\right )\mathclose {}} and so we may compute our identification \bar \rho \, a as follows:
Above we have used the fact that the coherence datum \eta _{p_{I}}a is reflexivity.
Our main theorem then follows from wild categorical considerations, as we show below.

fr:title.text: The main result: reflectivity of impredicative subuniverses

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The main result: reflectivity of impredicative subuniverses

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} be an impredicative pair of universes with A:\mathcal {V}. There we may construct a reflection algebra A_{\mathcal {U}} :{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}} such that for any other reflection algebra X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}, the space of homomorphisms A_{\mathcal {U}}\multimap X is contractible.

Our splitting of the generic element of the generic cone {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{p}}{1_{{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}}} over the identity functor on reflection algebras yields a new (incoherent) cone {\Delta J}\xrightarrow {{q}}{1_{{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}}} whose generic element q_{J}:J\multimap J may be identified with the identity homomorphism. It follows that each space of homomorphisms J\to X is contractible. Therefore, we define A_{\mathcal {U}} to be the apex J.
If \mathcal {U}\in \mathcal {V} is an impredicative pair of universes, then \mathcal {U} is reflective in \mathcal {V}.
Our construction of the initial reflection algebra for each A:\mathcal {V} is one of several equivalent formulations of reflective subuniverse in univalent foundations.
